WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser has implemented all aspects of the RMP/PSM Program. When a RMP/PSM Program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP/PSM Program implementation.

WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser considers the RMP/PSM Program a “living document”. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP/PSM Program WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser will continue to maintain overall plant worker, public, and environmental safety.

1.5.2 Emergency Response Notification Exercises

At least once per calendar year, WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser will conduct an exercise of the facility’s emergency response notifications mechanism. The facility will record each notification exercise utilizing PSMWriter.

Alternatively, the facility may meet the notification requirements through other exercises conducted to meet other Federal, state or local requirements, provided that the necessary notification is performed. Additionally, if a notification is made in response to an accidental release, this would also satisfy the notification requirement.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.
WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

WM Bolthouse Farms, Inc - Prosser has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.2 Process Descriptions

1.2.1 Facility Overview

Bolthouse Farms operates a food processing plant primarily for carrots and other produce in Prosser, WA. The facility has two (2) ammonia refrigeration systems named Systems 1-2 and System 3. The systems provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

System 1-2
Cello Hydrocooler
Cut Hydrocooler
Cello Cold Storage
West Bagger Room
Pack Storage West
Peel Hydrocooler

System 3
Glycol Chiller HX-1

1.2.2 Facility Location

Bolthouse Farms Prosser is located at 10 Sonova Rd. Prosser, WA 99350. The latitude and longitude of the Machinery Room 2 high pressure receiver, located outside, is 45.877030, -119.905951. The facility is located approximately 2.8 miles north of state highway 14 and the Columbia River which forms a border between Oregon and Washington in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is not located in a special flood hazard area.
A review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Bolthouse Farms Prosser had a 1-2% chance of experiencing “potentially minor-damage” due to ground shaking in 2018.

1.2.3 Description of Covered Processes

The air-cooling evaporators and hydrocoolers in the refrigeration systems are supplied from surge drums as required for flooded operation.
